Let me show you a test that was done, an experiment that was done.
So this one was a keyboard test that involved two different asks.
This is a Harvard test called the implicit association test iat and what they did first was they asked users to look at different pictures of individuals and label them as black or white.
And they would put the categorization by typing a key on the left of the keyboard and the right of the key.
And the ask was sometimes they would ask to put white on one side like the left side.
And sometimes they would ask for white to be on the other side.
They would be switching where the individual was bucketized.
Okay, so this is one test, you may say, if that itself is kind of an Odd test to do, but their idea was to then do something else.
They had a separate test where they ask you when you see a word, if that word has a good association, you put it on one side.
If that word has a bad association, you put it on the other side.
So again, it's a bucketization task where you're being asked to assess things that are coming on the screen and put it in the right bucket.
So what they varied for this test was whether they lined up white with good or black with good.
And what I mean by good is that the bucket's on the same side.
But the ask of where you're bucket sizing was based on either they're both left or both right.
So this gap here in time, this is based on the amount of time it took to do this test.

It found that there was a significant difference in how people that were taking this test perceived the combination of the two, how easy it was for them to do this exercise when they paired white with good versus black with good.
This is one indication of an implicit bias.
